claim: Darth Vader says to Luke in The Empire Strikes Back, Obi-Wan never told you what happened to your father.

supporting.text: In 'The Empire Strikes Back,' Darth Vader explicitly states to Luke, 'Obi-Wan never told you what happened to your father,' which is a direct quote from the film.

attacks.text: In 'The Empire Strikes Back,' Darth Vader explicitly states to Luke, 'Obi-Wan never told you what happened to your father,' which is a direct quote from the film.
The quote may be accurate, but Vader's statement is deceptive because Obi-Wan did tell Luke that Vader betrayed and murdered his father, which is a half-truth.
The context of the quote is important—Vader is manipulating Luke emotionally, so the statement may not be taken at face value as a factual claim.
Obi-Wan's version of events was also misleading, as he withheld the full truth that Vader and Luke's father were the same person.
Vader's manipulation does not negate the literal truth of his statement—Obi-Wan indeed never told Luke that Vader was his father.
Obi-Wan's omission was arguably justified to protect Luke until he was ready to confront the truth, making Vader's statement technically true but morally loaded.

supporting.text: The dialogue between Darth Vader and Luke in the Cloud City scene includes this line, confirming its authenticity in the script.

attacks.text: The dialogue between Darth Vader and Luke in the Cloud City scene includes this line, confirming its authenticity in the script.
The script could have been altered or misremembered by those recalling the scene, casting doubt on the exact wording.
The authenticity of the script does not necessarily confirm the truthfulness of Darth Vader's statement within the narrative.
Scripts for major films like The Empire Strikes Back are meticulously documented and preserved, making alterations unlikely.
Darth Vader's statement is consistent with his character's motivations and the plot, supporting its narrative truthfulness.
Even with meticulous documentation, human error or intentional revisions during production could lead to discrepancies.

supporting.text: There is no evidence in the original trilogy that contradicts this statement, reinforcing its validity.

attacks.text: There is no evidence in the original trilogy that contradicts this statement, reinforcing its validity.
The statement is misleading because Obi-Wan did tell Luke about his father, albeit in a different context.
The absence of contradiction does not necessarily imply validity, as it could be an omission or oversight.
Obi-Wan's version of events was intentionally vague and omitted key details, making Darth Vader's statement technically true.
The original trilogy's narrative consistency supports the idea that omissions are deliberate, not oversights.
Obi-Wan's vagueness was a protective measure, not deceit, so Vader's framing is still manipulative.
Deliberate omissions can still undermine validity if they create a false impression, which Vader exploits.

supporting.text: Obi-Wan's earlier statement to Luke that Darth Vader 'betrayed and murdered your father' could imply he withheld the full truth, supporting Vader's claim.

attacks.text: Obi-Wan's earlier statement to Luke that Darth Vader 'betrayed and murdered your father' could imply he withheld the full truth, supporting Vader's claim.
Obi-Wan might have used metaphorical language to simplify the complex truth for Luke, not necessarily withholding information maliciously.
The statement could be interpreted as a literal truth if 'murder' refers to the destruction of Anakin Skywalker's identity, not his physical body.
Obi-Wan had a duty to protect Luke from traumatic truths until he was emotionally ready, justifying any omission.
The Jedi Order's philosophy often involves poetic or symbolic language, making Obi-Wan's phrasing consistent with their teachings rather than deceptive.
Vader's claim itself is manipulative, casting doubt on whether Obi-Wan's phrasing was truly misleading.
Delaying traumatic truths can cause greater harm when revealed later, undermining Obi-Wan's protective intent.
Luke's eventual reaction to the truth suggests he was unprepared despite Obi-Wan's efforts, weakening the 'protective' justification.

attacks.text: The claim could be false if the line was dubbed or altered in later releases, but there is no evidence of such changes.
Film historians and archives confirm that no alterations were made to this line in any official release of The Empire Strikes Back.
Actor James Earl Jones, who voiced Darth Vader, has never mentioned any dubbing changes to this specific line in interviews or memoirs.
The original 1980 theatrical script and subsequent releases show identical dialogue, contradicting the possibility of alteration.
Film preservation standards for major franchises like Star Wars make unauthorized alterations highly improbable without public documentation.
James Earl Jones' silence doesn't prove absence of changes, as voice actors aren't always consulted for minor post-production edits.
